awd_titl_txt: The Formation and Architecture of Circumbinary Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will fund a numerical study of circumbinary planets (those which orbit two stars instead of one) in order to provide a strong dynamical framework for understanding planet formation and interpreting data from ongoing and upcoming exoplanet surveys.  Roughly half the stars in the Galaxy are in binaries, and understanding how the planetary masses and orbits are different in these systems is essential to both a full theory of planetary formation and undestanding sites of habitability.  The PI and her team will train and mentor graduate and undergraduate students in research with a focus on computational astrophysics.  She will also provide educational resources to the University of Arizona Astronomy camp program. 

The investigators will study dynamical packing in multi-planet systems for a range of binary configurations, and will also carry out hydrodynamic simulations investigating planet-disk interaction in circumbinary systems.  They will develop tools to evaluate the role of multi-body resonances in setting stability timescales, implement new thermodynamic modules in FARGO, and predict transit signals that can be used to characterize circumbinary transit timing variations (TTVs).  They will use the model transit signals to predict the kinds of planetary systems which will be observable by future surveys.

por.por_cntn:
This grant funded research into the origins of planets in binary star systems. In particular, the project was aimed at a special type of binaries that have an outsize impact on astronomy and even life on Earth. Our research was focused primarily on very close binaries, those that might ultimately interact and generate many heavy elements crucial to life on Earth. By studying the origins of planets in these systems, we both characterize unique planetary systems and learn about the formation of the host binaries. The noteworthy intellectual merits of our work are:

1) Our work revealed that evolution of the orbits of planets in binaries should proceed in a mostly similar fashion as around single star systems. The notable exception is that planets in binary systems undergo far fewer collisions with other planets and the host star than their single-star counterparts. This could affect how polluted a star becomes with extra heavy elements, as well as the expected number of free floating planets in the galaxy. This work also showed that underlying differences in the planet populations around single versus binary stars should derive from early formation, rather than later stage evolution. (Smullen et al 2016)

2) The research techniques we have developed were subsequently applied to the Pluto-Charon satellite system in our our Solar System. We were able to show that the cratering record on Pluto and Charon should be a pristine representation of Kuiper Belt impacts, unpolluted by satellite formation and evolution. We also predict the possibility of the existence of a Pluto-Charon family of small Kuiper Belt objects left over from the formation of the satellite systems. Such bodies might be discoverable with future surveys like LSST. (Smullen and Kratter 2017)

3) The final major outcome was the discover of a series of instabilities that can only arise in multi-planet  systems around close due to a complex interplay between resonances. We show that the early evolution of multi-planet systems in binaries requires a very stable orbit for the host binary, confirming that the host binary must form early to retain closely packed systems of planets. We also show that there are some plausible mechanisms to make binaries that host planets quickly enough to be consistent with the observations. This work is motivating follow up study that will help constrain how tides affect the evolution of binaries and their planets. (Sutherland and Kratter, 2019, Moe & Kratter 2018)

This grant also supported broader impacts on the community through engagement with K-12 students, undergraduates, and the general public. Each summer, team members served as assistants and lecturers in the University of Arizona’s Astronomy Camp, where they helped engage aspiring young scientists. In addition, the PI presented work related to the project to the general public, including returning veterans, at a variety of venues, including universities, amateur astronomy clubs and media appearances (radio and television).
